name: 1-(3-methoxybenzoyl)-2-(1-naphthoyl)hydrazine
Reason: 1-(3-methoxybenzoyl)-2-(1-naphthoyl)hydrazine has a complex structure with multiple functional groups. The basic unit for comparison can be benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C (according to the CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics, 49th Edition, 1968-1969). The structural modifications we need to consider are the presence of two additional phenyl rings, a methoxy group, a benzoyl group, and a naphthoyl group. Phenyl groups, when connected to a benzene ring, tend to increase the melting point due to the enhancement of the crystalline structure and the increase in molecular weight. The methoxy group introduces additional hydrogen bonding potential, which can further lower the melting point. The benzoyl group introduces additional rigidity and hydrogen bonding potential, which can raise the melting point. The naphthoyl group introduces additional rigidity and hydrogen bonding potential, which can raise the melting point. Each additional phenyl group can be estimated to add approximately 100°C to the melting point due to increased pi-pi interactions, rigidity, and molecular weight. The methoxy group can also contribute to the melting point due to increased hydrogen bonding, estimated at around +20°C. The benzoyl group can also contribute to the melting point due to increased rigidity and hydrogen bonding, estimated at around +30°C. The naphthoyl group can also contribute to the melting point due to increased rigidity and hydrogen bonding, estimated at around +40°C.
